postgresql.description: CPU shares to allocate to each service instance.

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each PostgreSQL node.

mem.description: Memory to allocate to each service instance.

dbname.description: Name for the default database that is created when the image is first started.

initdbargs.description: Arguments to send to postgres initdb. The value is a space separated string of arguments as postgres initdb would expect them.

host_volume.description: If using non-persistent volumes (local volumes), this sets the location of a volume on the host to be used for the service. The final location will be derived from this value plus the name set in `name` (e.g. `/mnt/host_volume/service_name`). This can be a mounted NFS drive. Note that this path must be the same on all DC/OS agents. NOTE: if you don't change the default /tmp value, YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.

volume_size.description: If a new volume is to be created, this controls its size in MBs.

enable.description: Enable or disable external persistent storage. The `persistence` option must also be selected. Please note that for these to work, your DC/OS cluster MUST have been installed with the right options in `config.yaml`. Also, please note this requires a working  configuration file for the driver (e.g. `rexray.yaml`).

volume_name.description: Name that your volume driver uses to look up your external volume. When your task is staged on an agent, the volume driver queries the storage service for a volume with this name. If one does not exist, it is created implicitly. Otherwise, the existing volume is reused.

provider.description: Provider of the external persistent volume. The default value should be correct for most use cases.

driver.description: Volume driver to use for storage. The default value should be correct for most use cases.

port.description: Port number to be used for clear communication internally to the cluster.

host_mode.description: Enable or disable host networking mode. NOTE: this requires the default port to be available on the target host. This also forces to have a single instance per node.

external_access.description:
Enable access from outside the cluster through Marathon-LB.
NOTE: this connection is unencrypted.

enable.description: Enable or disable creating a VIP for external access through a public node running Marathon-LB.

external_access_port.description: For external access, port number to be used for clear communication in the external Marathon-LB load balancer
